text:
That will be your liability for capital gains. We will split the capital loss in jt fidelity account which is about 70k.
In mediation, you had option to transfer some of your 401k to equalize me. Your 401k continues to appreciate and you have benefited from
those gains since oct 31 and I have not, but decided instead to give me cash immediately which our side assumed was factored into your offer
but that was speculation on our part. By doing so  you would bear those capital gains from resulting stock sales to generate the cash. That was
the trade off that we speculated you did. You kept gains in 401k but took hit on capital gains on sale.
I agreed to Jan 1, but that also means you need to have that cash ready that date. I assumed you would need to sell stock prior to that.
On 12/12/2024 at 06:58 AM, Christine Moyer wrote:
To:Robert Moyer (First Viewed: 12/12/2024 at 07:03 AM)
Subject:Re: Safeco/Fidelity
I am.
Our agreement for 2024, even though we file joint, we pay taxes based on what issued to us.
I’ll pay on my w2 and get credit for any withholding, my capital gains from my stock sales, and will take my share of capital losses from the jt
fidelity.
You will pay on your unemployment income, deferred comp income, capital gains from the fidelity msft account and losses from jt account.
Washington state has capital gains tax for amounts greater than 250k as well for this and next year.
That might factor into your calc for next year once we sell the home.
On 12/12/2024 at 06:38 AM, Robert Moyer wrote:
To:Christine Moyer (First Viewed: 12/12/2024 at 06:51 AM)
Subject:Re: Safeco/Fidelity
I have all the stock sales (I’ll share in email).
It’s the cost basis that I need to figure out.
Are you open to the payment a day later?
On 12/12/2024 at 06:29 AM, Christine Moyer wrote:
To:Robert Moyer (First Viewed: 12/12/2024 at 06:36 AM)
Subject:Re: Safeco/Fidelity
I have some math I’ll share later today.
On 12/11/2024 at 10:06 PM, Robert Moyer wrote:
To:Christine Moyer (First Viewed: 12/12/2024 at 06:28 AM)
Subject:Re: Safeco/Fidelity
Specific to the 300k... I am running some numbers.
Today we are in the 35% bracket. I need to sell 200k to pay off everything and move things around. Then, if I sell the 300K, we will push to the
next bracket, and our tax bill will go up. Below is my calculation based on that.
<<Caveat: I know I am mixing annual income with realized gains and need to distinguish:>>
